title: Roberto Antonelli
text:
Roberto Antonelli (born 29 May 1953) is a former Italian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and player who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Striker">striker</a> or as an <a href="Midfielder%23Attacking%20midfielder">attacking midfielder</a>.
Club career.
A highly talented yet humble player, throughout his career, Antonelli played for Italian clubs <a href="A.C.%20Monza%20Brianza%201912">Monza</a>, <a href="Vicenza%20Calcio">Vicenza</a>, <a href="A.C.%20Milan">A.C. Milan</a>, <a href="Genoa%20C.F.C.">Genoa</a>, and <a href="A.S.%20Roma">Roma</a>. He contributed to Milan's tenth league title victory during the <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20Serie%20A">1978–79 Serie A</a> season with 21 appearances and 5 goals; following Milan's relegation after their involvement in the <a href="Totonero%201980">Totonero 1980</a> match-fixing scandal, he remained with the club and played a decisive role in helping the team win the <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Serie%20B">Serie B title in 1981</a> and earn promotion to Serie A, scoring 15 goals, and finishing the season as the top scorer in Serie B.
Personal life.
His son <a href="Luca%20Antonelli">Luca Antonelli</a> is a professional footballer, currently playing for Empoli as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">left back</a>. Throughout his career, Roberto earned the nickname "Dustin", due to his resemblance to the actor <a href="Dustin%20Hoffman">Dustin Hoffman</a>.
Honours.
Club.
A.C. Milan
